title: Standing waves - frequencies for 3 and 5 antinodes

content.question: The figure shows two identical strings, String <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and String <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, that each have a standing wave. The strings have the same length <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> and tension <math alttext="uppercase F sub T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></math>. What is the frequency of the standing wave on String <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> in terms of the frequency <math alttext="f sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> of the standing wave on String <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="three fifths f sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="five thirds f sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="2 times f sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="five thirds f sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
